astroImageInfo.title: The Flaming Star Nebula in SHO
The Elephants Trunk Nebula in SHO
The Elephants Trunk Nebula in HOO
The Heart Nebula
astroImageInfo.description: First light with my new ZWO ASI 533MM Pro camera, and my first mono image! I've finally jumped on to the mono bandwagon and I can see what all the fuss is about now. It's more work sure, but the extra detail and contrast is instantly noticeable in the image. The Heart Nebula (IC 1805) was also one of the first images I took with the 533MC Pro when I first got it, and it's crazy to see the difference in image quality and processing skills compared to that!

astroImageInfo.title: The Andromeda Galaxy
astroImageInfo.description: This image was taken over a few nights across a few weeks. The first capture session had around 7hrs of data, and an additional 3 were added a few weeks after.

astroImageInfo.title: The Ghost of Cassiopeia
astroImageInfo.description: This is IC63, or more commonly known as the Ghost of Cassiopeia. This is quite a challenging target from my location as it’s faint and is both a broadband and narrowband target. I captured this over 2 nights using both the Optolong L-Pro for the broadband data and L-Extreme for the narrowband (Ha), and combined them in PixInsight.

astroImageInfo.title: The Rosette Nebula
astroImageInfo.description: This is my latest image of the Rosette Nebula & star cluster within (NGC2244). I’ve been waiting all year to image this and got my chance this week with a run of clear nights! It was also my first image processed with BlurXTerminator, which is beyond amazing! I’m really happy with how this turned out.

astroImageInfo.title: Louie's Star
astroImageInfo.description: What you’re looking at is my very own star, purchased by my lovely wife for Christmas through NameAStar. The star is located in the constellation Gemini and is now registered and named after our cat, Louie (or more specifically after his nickname ‘El Louile’). Louie, your name is now (literally) written in the stars!

astroImageInfo.title: Bodes & Cigar Galaxy
astroImageInfo.description: After what felt like forever I finally had a run of clear nights this week so made the most of it. I decided to image M81 and M82 again with my 130PDS as it had a longer focal length than the 72ED I previously used. In total I managed to get about 10hrs of broadband and 3 hours of L-Extreme data for the Ha regions. I would have liked to get more but the weather has unfortunately gone back to normal (rain and clouds)!

astroImageInfo.title: The Tadpoles Nebula
astroImageInfo.description: This is the Tadpoles Nebula in the constellation Auriga (IC410). I started to capture data on this nebula back in December, in between other targets and ended up with about 5 hours of data. I added another 6.5 hours last night and this is the result! This is probably the longest I've spent acquiring data on a single target so far (2 months), as when the moon is out it sits slap bang in the middle of Auriga from my position, so I've had to wait for clear AND moonless nights to finish this!

astroImageInfo.title: The Orion Nebula
astroImageInfo.description: This is this year's capture of the Orion and Running Man Nebula (M42). It'll probably become an annual thing! I'm very happy with how the final image turned out. I'm actually using less data than my last attempt, but the data itself was better and my processing has improved a lot, which has resulted in a much better image in my opinion. I blended broadband and narrowband data at different exposure times for the core and star detail, which has made a big difference when compared to narrowband only as in my last attempt.

astroImageInfo.title: The Triangulum Galaxy
astroImageInfo.description: This is a blend of old and new data, taken with the 72ED and 130PDS.

astroImageInfo.title: The Iris Nebula
astroImageInfo.description: This image was taken over a few nights across a few weeks. The first capture session had around 7hrs of data, and an additional 3 were added a few weeks after.

astroImageInfo.title: Hercules Star Cluster
astroImageInfo.description: This image was taken over a few nights across a few weeks.

astroImageInfo.title: A Section of the Question Mark Nebula
astroImageInfo.description: This image was taken over a number of nights when we had a rare week of clear skies! When processing in PixInsight, I was playing around with the curves values for the individual colour channels and accidentally created this orange-blue colour palette which I really like, so I stuck with it to produce this image.

astroImageInfo.title: The Cygnus Loop
astroImageInfo.description: This is a 4-panel mosaic of the Cygnus Loop, containing the Eastern & Western Veil Nebula, Pickerings Triangle, and more. It was captured during the month of June 2022 with around 4.5hrs worth of data for each panel.

astroImageInfo.title: The North America & Pelican Nebula
astroImageInfo.description: This is the North America and Pelican nebula in the constellation Cygnus. The North America nebula was the first nebula I ever took a photo of so it’s good to revisit it! This is a 4-panel mosaic taken throughout August. Each panel is between 5-6 hours of data each, and was processed on HOO.

astroImageInfo.title: The Lion Nebula
astroImageInfo.description: This image was taken over 3 consecutive nights. It is quite a faint target and light pollution in my area meant gathering quite a bit of data to bring out as much detail as possible.

astroImageInfo.title: The Eastern Veil Nebula
astroImageInfo.description: This image was taken in a single night in September, and was first light for my Skywatcher 130PDS telescope.

astroImageInfo.title: The Pacman Nebula
astroImageInfo.description: I initially captured this back in Jan '22, but only had around 2hrs worth of data to work with. I've combined this with 4 more hrs of new data that was taken in August '22, and this is the result.

astroImageInfo.title: Casper the Friendly Ghost Nebula
astroImageInfo.description: This is M78 in the constellation Orion. I planned to get a lot of data on this target but only managed to get around 5hrs. Unfortunately, the weather has been awful the last few weeks and I want to capture another nebula before Orion disappears, so I'm calling it a day on M78 for now.

astroImageInfo.title: The Jellyfish Nebula
astroImageInfo.description: This is the Jellyfish Nebula (IC443). I have been wanting to capture this for a while so I took the opportunity this week while we had a run of clear nights to get it. This is around 15 hours of data in both RGB and Narrowband using the L-Pro and L-eXtreme filters.

astroImageInfo.title: Comet E3 2022 ZTF
astroImageInfo.description: This comet has been doing the rounds recently so I thought I'd have a go myself! It's called Comet E3 2022 (ZTF), and was only discovered last year. It orbits every 50,000 years making this a literal once-in-a-lifetime opportunity, and also means it would have last been seen by our early ancestors! This is 60x 60s exposures taken on the 23rd Jan.

astroImageInfo.title: SN2023IXF Supernova in the Pinwheel Galaxy
astroImageInfo.description:
21 million lightyears ago, a star went supernova and exploded in M101, the Pinwheel Galaxy.

The light emitted from that supernova has travelled those 21 million years to end its journey on my camera sensor, resulting in this image - SN2023IXF Supernovae are so bright they outshine the galaxy they reside in, making this look like a star in our own galaxy despite the fact it’s trillions of miles away!
